bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, January 17, 1876

div1.p: Reed has received no letter from her, but offers a meditation on patience.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, January 17, 1876
div1.opener:
C1
B9
Willet's Point, N.Y.H.
January 17th 76-
My Sweet, little E.;
div1.p:
It is
evening, ere I begin my let-
ter. Have been as busy as pos-
sible all day, & feel very
much fatigued, to-night- Am
a little bit disappointed, too,
in not receiving any letter
from you, to-day- Why, oh! why
will the sweetest woman in
the world continue to dis-
appoint my expectations? Is
it that she thinks, if delayed,
it will be more acceptable
when it arrives, at last? If so,
I am almost compelled to
acknowledge that there is
a good deal of truth in it-
I am not complaining, my
precious- only making a few
inquiries- Before going farther,
permit me, my darling E., to
congratulate you on the arri-
val of your birth-day- You see,
although I forgot my own,
I did not forget yours- Far
from such being the case,
I thought of it days before
it arrived, & on that day remem-
bered you an hundred times, and
if the wishes & prayers that as-
cended from my heart, on that
day, could avail aught, your
future would be indeed bright
& happy! As, indeed, I firmly
believe it will be. Certainly, my
darling, when I think of the fact
of your having confided your
love to my keeping, there is
nothing that I would not do
to make you happy- I would
fain forget myself & think
only of you. Do you know, my
darling, that very often when
I am perplexed with some
labor that is before me, Iinstead
of permitting it to harrass
me, I say to my heart: “be brave;
for the sake of her who is dear
to you above others, & who is watch-
ing your career with an af-
fectionate interest- Do your
work nobly & dismiss all thoughts
of self-” Thus, my darling E.,
do I escape much that would
otherwise trouble me- I feel
that I am learning lessons of
patience, more & more, every day,
which, I suppose, will be good
news to you. I am endeavouring
to teach myself that “sufficient
unto the day is the evil there-
of”. But Oh! such a hard lesson
it is to learn! Especially for one
who is governed too much
by his impulses- However, I
am striving, every day, to over-
come those impulses & subject
them to my better judgement-
In which endeavour, my darling
E., I beg that you will grant
me your prayers.

Excuse the brevity of my letter
& its abrupt termination, but
I feel too tired to write more-
In the next, I hope to make amends-
div1.closer:
Believe me, as ever,
my darling,
your fond & devoted Walter.
